questions.question: What is the location of the community?

tooltip.text: This question contains a list of possible household locations, starting with the government area or district, down to the village.
Record GPS coordinates of a central place in the community (e.g. community meeting place)
List of community roles

options.name: Village chief/Community head
Local Government official
Community Health Volunteer
Water/Sanitation/Hygiene Committee Member
School Principal/Teacher
Natural leader (CLTS)
Community Health Volunteer

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: how many households currently live in this community (village or urban neighbourhood), including temporary, migrant and seasonal visitors? Household: defined as a person or group of persons who: a) Are related or unrelated; b) live together in the same dwelling/housing unit (at least 4 nights a week); c) acknowledge one adult male or female as the head of household; d) share the same living arrangements; and e) are considered as one unit.
INTERVIEW: how many at-risk households have been identified in the community? At-risk households: households that meet the at-risk criteria determined by the County Public Health Office

INTERVIEW: what is the main soil type in this community? Soil type: what type of soil makes up the top 6 feet of the soil profile (only one type can be selected) Soil drainage: ask whether water soaks into the soil? If water soaks in quickly and easily, then it is likely to be a high drainage soil; if it soaks in at a normal rate, it is a medium drainage soil; and if water soaks in very slowly (or not at all) then it is a low drainage soil

options.name: Medium drainage soil (medium sand, weathered rock)
High drainage soil (coarse sand & gravel, fractured sandstone or limestone)
Low drainage soil (fine sand, silt or clay)

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: what is the average depth to the groundwater table in this community? Depth to groundwater: how many metres below ground is water found (e.g. depth from ground level to water in wells and boreholes)?

options.name: Less than 5m
Between 5-10m
More than 10m

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: what is the main water supply technology used in this community? Water supply technology: main system or facilities used to supply drinking water

options.name: Protected groundwater sources (protected boreholes, protected dug wells or protected springs)
Unprotected groundwater sources (boreholes, dug wells or springs)
No groundwater sources used

questions.question: Use of groundwater for drinking water supply

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: what percentage of households obtain drinking water from groundwater sources in this community? Obtained from groundwater sources: drinking water is collected from water supplies or water points that produce water from below ground (boreholes, dug wells or springs)

options.name: More than 25%
Between 1% and 25%
0% (zero percent)

questions.question: Distance of toilets from groundwater sources

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: what percentage of household toilets are located less than 10m from groundwater sources?
Toilet distance from groundwater source: the horizontal distance (along the ground) between the toilet and the nearest groundwater source (borehole, dug well or spring)

options.name: More than 25%
Less than 25%

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: what percentage of household toilets are located uphill from (above) the nearest groundwater sources?
Toilet uphill of groundwater source: the toilet is located at a higher point than (above) the groundwater source (borehole, dug well or spring)

options.name: More than 25%
Less than 25%

questions.question: COMMUNITY LEVEL ASSESSMENT: Low risk of groundwater contamination

options.name: G0 High risk of groundwater contamination
G2 Low risk of groundwater contamination

questions.question: G1: Number of households who own a toilet

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: how many households in the community currently own a toilet?
Households who own a toilet: current information based on latest community monitoring information (for households who have their own toilet)

questions.question: G2: Number of households using durable toilets with safe containment

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: how many households in the community currently use a durable toilet with safe containment?
Households who use a durable toilet with safe containment: current information based on latest community monitoring information (for households who have durable toilets with safe containment)

questions.question: G3: Number of households with permanent handwashing stations

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: how many households in the community own permanent handwashing stations?
Households with permanent handwashing stations: current information based on latest community monitoring information (for households with permanent handwashing stations)

INTERVIEW: has an action plan for G2 status been approved?
INTERVIEW: is the action plan for G2 status in use?

options.name: G0 Action plan for G2: not available, not approved or not in use
G1 Action plan for G2: available and in use

INTERVIEW: has an action plan for G3 status been approved?
INTERVIEW: is the action plan for G3 status in use?

options.name: G0 Action plan for G3: not available, not approved or not in use
G1 Action plan for G3: available and in use

questions.question: No exposed human excreta in communal areas

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: visible human faeces in communal areas
Open defecation in water bodies: where groups or communities may practice open defecation in nearby water bodies (for example, people living near beaches, lakes and rivers), human excreta may not be visible in communal areas. In these cases, household interviews should be undertaken to assess whether people practice open defecation (including in water bodies) or use a toilet, in combination of observation of the presence of a functional toilet (to verify claims of toilet use).
Communal areas: areas within the community that are not part of household compounds, and which are accessible to all.

options.name: G0 Child or adult excreta observed in communal areas
G1 No visible OD or human excreta (child or adult) in communal areas

questions.question: Outcome result - No exposed human excreta

fn.fnString: function(){ return (#1699959649782.includes("G1")) ? "G1 No exposed human excreta in compound" : "G0 Child or adult excreta observed in compound" }

questions.question: Safe management of diapers in communal areas

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: no used diapers visible in communal areas
Safe management of washable cloths: where washable cloths are used to contain child excreta, the cloths should be cleaned and washed in a safe place (for example, so that the child excreta do not contaminate the compound or a water point) and any faeces contained in the cloth should be safely disposed (for example, put or rinsed into the toilet, or buried).
Safe management of disposable diapers: where disposable diapers are used to contain child excreta, the diapers should be properly closed and EITHER disposed to a covered waste pit, OR buried, OR collected for disposal at a safely managed communal disposal site. 
Communal areas: areas within the community that are not part of household compounds, and which are accessible to all.

options.name: G0 Used diapers visible in communal areas
G0 Used diapers unsafely disposed or unsafely washed
G1 Washable cloths safely emptied and safely washed
G1 Disposable diapers put into covered waste pits
G1 Disposable diapers buried
G1 Disposable diapers collected for disposal at communal site

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of diapers

fn.fnString: function(){ return (#1699959743410.includes("G1")) ? "G1 Safely managed diapers" : "G0 Diapers UNSAFELY managed" }

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: cleanliness of water points in communal areas
Clean water points: free from debris, solid waste, human or animal faeces, and any other potential sources of contamination
Communal areas: areas within the community that are not part of household compounds, and which are accessible to all.

options.name: G0 Visible dirt or contamination
G1 Not adequately clean
G2 Clean communal water points

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: protection of water points in communal areas
Protected surface water sources (pans, dams, lakes, rivers): fenced to prevent animal access
Protected water supply source catchments: protected from wastes and pollutants, including human excreta and animal wastes (for example, by excluding animals and prohibiting unsafe activities, such as the use of manure or chemical fertilisers in areas around water supply sources).
Protected water points: provide separate water troughs for animal watering
Protected groundwater sources (springs, wells, handpumps, boreholes): protected from contamination, wastes and pollutants (for example, by the construction of a spring box, raised parapet wall and cover, wellhead protection and sealed borehole casing).

options.name: G0 No protection of water points
G1 Inadequate protection of water points
G2 Well protected communal water points

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: drainage of water points in communal areas
Well drained water points: no standing water visible at or around the water source (provision of drainage and soakpits may be required in slow-draining soils)

options.name: G0 Standing water visible around water point
G1 Inadequately drained water points
G2 Well drained communal water points

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of communal water sources

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: evidence of unsafe faecal sludge disposal in communal areas?
INTERVIEW: is any faecal sludge disposed to communal areas?
INTERVIEW: is any faecal sludge buried in communal areas?
Communal areas: areas within the community that are not part of household compounds, and which are accessible to all.

options.name: G0 Unsafe disposal: to open pit, open space, open drain or water body in communal areas
G0 Unsafe treatment or disposal: sewer connection to open discharge in communal area
G3 Safely managed: emptied to covered pit or trench in communal area
G3 Safely managed: communal disposal of faecal sludge is safely managed

questions.question: Outcome result - Use of safely managed sanitation services

fn.fnString: function(){ return (#1699960255414.includes("G0")) ? "G0 Sanitation services UNSAFELY managed in communal areas" : (#1699960255414.includes("G3") ? "G3 Use of safely managed sanitation services in communal areas" : "G1 Inadequate sanitation services in communal areas") }

questions.question: Drainage for stormwater in communal areas

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: erosion or other damage caused by stormwater flows in communal areas
Stormwater: surface water from rainfall or storms.
Adequate stormwater drainage: drains or other services that limit or prevent erosion from stormwater flows (for example, EITHER by transporting flows away from communal areas, OR by encouraging infiltration into the soil)
Communal areas: areas within the community that are not part of household compounds, and which are accessible to all.

options.name: G0 Significant erosion in communal areas
G1 Some visible erosion in communal areas
G3 Adequate stormwater drainage in communal areas
G3 No signs of stormwater erosion

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of liquid wastes

fn.fnString: function(){ return (#1699960354498.includes("G0")) ? "G1 Liquid wastes UNSAFELY managed in communal areas" : (#1699960354498.includes("G3") ? "G3 Safe management of liquid wastes in communal areas" : "G2 Inadequate management of liquid wastes in communal areas") }

questions.question: No visible solid wastes in communal areas

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: visible solid wastes in communal areas
Solid wastes: food wastes, paper, plastic, rags, metal, glass and other solid materials discarded by the household
Communal areas: areas within the community that are not part of household compounds, and which are accessible to all.

options.name: G0 Significant visible solid wastes in communal areas
G1 Some solid wastes visible in communal areas
G3 Clean compound with no visible solid wastes in communal areas

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of solid wastes

fn.fnString: function(){ return (#1699960411329.includes("G0")) ? "G1 Liquid wastes UNSAFELY managed in communal areas" : (#1699960411329.includes("G3") ? "G3 Safe management of liquid wastes in communal areas" : "G2 Inadequate management of liquid wastes in communal areas") }

questions.question: No standing water in communal areas

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: visible standing water in communal areas
Standing water: accumulation of wastewater (or stormwater) in communal area, which does NOT immediately drain away
Communal areas: areas within the community that are not part of household compounds, and which are accessible to all.

options.name: G0 Significant standing water in communal areas
G3 No visible standing water in communal areas
G1 Some standing water in communal areas

questions.question: Treated larval breeding sites in communal areas

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: where standing water provides larval breeding sites in communal areas, are treatment or other vector control activities used to limit mosquito breeding?
Larval breeding sites: mosquitoes lay eggs directly in or near water, soil and at the base of plants in places that may fill with water.
Vector control activities: draining of standing water; covering of water storage containers; filling of depressions that hold water; filling of cracks in water tank and septic tank covers; cover open vents or plumbing pipes (with insect screen).
Treatment activities: use of larvicides to treat bodies of water that will not be used for drinking, and which cannot be covered, emptied or removed; use of fogging or surface applications to control adult mosquitoes

options.name: G0 No treatment or management in communal areas
G1 Inadequate treatment or management in communal areas
G3 Treated or managed larval breeding sites in communal areas
G3 No visible standing water in communal areas

questions.question: Outcome result - Good vector control in communal areas

fn.fnString: function(){ return (#1699960488230.includes("G0") && #1699960542156.includes("G0")) ? "G1 Lack of vector control in communal areas" : ((#1699960488230.includes("G3") && #1699960542156.includes("G3")) ? "G3 Good vector control in communal areas" : "G2 Inadequate vector control in communal areas") }

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: type of institution (located within community)
Institution: any public building with open access to the communal toilets and handwashing facilities

options.name: School
Healthcare facility
Transport station (bus, train, airport, fuel, other)
Market
Public toilet
Government office/building
Camps (fishing, mining, farming)
Worship centres (churches, cathedrals, mosques, temples, other)
Burial place
Prisons
Private institutions (hotels, guesthouses, restaurants, offices, factories, centres of learning, nursing homes)

options.name: G0 Non-functional toilets in institutions
G3 Functional toilets in all institutions

options.name: G0 Toilets NOT flyproof in institutions
G3 Flyproof toilets in all institutions

options.name: G0 Toilets NOT clean in institutions
G3 Clean toilets in all institutions

options.name: G0 Toilet slabs NOT durable in institutions
G3 Durable toilet slabs in all institutions

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: durable toilet pits  observed in all institutions?

options.name: G0 Toilet pits NOT durable in institutions
G3 Durable toilet pits in all institutions

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: any evidence of surface outflows from containment systems (for example, visible outflows or leaks; increased vegetation growth around the pit; visible deposits from previous outflows)
Surface outflows from containment: EITHER continuous outflows of faecal sludge or wastewater from overflow pipes, holes or leaks; OR evidence of previous surface outflows (for example, increased vegetation growth around the containment system, or visible sludge deposits from overflows or leaks).

options.name: G0 Visible surface outflows from containment
G1 Evidence of previous surface outflows from containment
G3 Safely managed containment in all institutions

questions.question: Safely managed on-site containment in institutional toilet

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: has the institutional toilet containment (pit, tank or other) ever been emptied?
INTERVIEW: has the institutional toilet containment (pit, tank or other) ever filled up?
INTERVIEW: what happened when the institutional toilet containment (pit, tank or other) last filled up?

options.name: G0 Unsafe containment: overflow to open space, open drain, water body
G3 Never emptied, not yet full (first toilet)
G3 Never emptied, previous pit or tank replaced when full

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: the last time it was emptied, where were the contents of the toilet containment emptied to?
INTERVIEW: the last time it was emptied, who emptied the toilet containment?
INTERVIEW (if the containment system is a lined pit or tank, which has never been emptied): what will happen when the toilet containment is full?
Licensed service provider: paid emptier that is approved and regulated by local authority to empty and transport toilet wastes
Unlicensed service provider: paid or unpaid emptier who is NOT approved by local authority to empty and transport toilet wastes (for example, family members, neighbours, friends, informal local emptiers) 
Off-site location: site for the treatment, disposal or use of toilet wastes that is away from the household/community, whose location may or may not be known to the household.
Sewer connection to licensed and functional treatment site: the Public Health Office should check whether the sewer network flows to a licensed and functional treatment or disposal site.

options.name: G0 No toilet, or no containment/collection system
G0 Unsafe containment: open container
G0 Unsafe disposal: to open pit, open space, open drain or water body (within 500m)
G0 Unsafe disposal: to open space, open drain or water body (MORE than 500m)
G0 Unsafe treatment or disposal: emptied by UNLICENSED service provider to off-site location
G0 Unsafe treatment or disposal: closed container removed by UNLICENSED service provider to off-site location
G0 Unsafe treatment or disposal: sewer connection to open discharge
G1 Risk of unsafe services: never emptied (intention to empty when full)
G1 Unsafe storage: stored for less than 2 years before use of stored waste
G1 Unsafe treatment or disposal: sewer connection to UNLICENSED or NON-FUNCTIONAL treatment site
G3 Safely managed: emptied to covered pit
G3 Safely managed: stored for MORE than 2 years before use of stored waste
G3 Safely managed: emptied by LICENSED service provider to off-site location
G3 Safely managed: closed container removed by LICENSED service provider to off-site location
G3 Safely managed: sewer connection to LICENSED and FUNCTIONAL treatment site

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: presence and location of handwashing facility
INTERVIEW: is there only one handwashing facility, or are other facilities available?

options.name: G0 No handwashing facility
G1 Handwashing facility by toilet
G1 Handwashing facility in kitchen
G1 Portable handwashing facility (basin, jug, jerrycan, container)
G1 Two handwashing facilities
G1 More than two handwashing facilities

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is water available at the handwashing facility?
OBSERVE: where an empty water container is observed at the handwashing facility, visible wet ground (or wet materials) under the handwashing facility can be accepted as proof of the recent presence of water.

options.name: G0 No water available
G1 Water available
G1 Water container empty (evidence of washing)

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is soap available at the handwashing facility?
INTERVIEW: is soap or detergent available for washing hands? 
Soap: solid, liquid or powder soap or detergent

options.name: G0 No soap or other cleanser available
G0 Ash, mud or sand available
G0+ Soap available, NOT at handwashing facility
G1 Solid, liquid or powder soap available

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is a permanent handwashing station available?
Permanent handwashing station: facility made from durable materials, with a piped water connection or adequate water storage, and located in a fixed place that is appropriate for handwashing at critical times
Market handwashing station: manufactured handwashing station from durable materails (bought from market or market trader)
Portable basin: open container that can be easily picked up and moved

options.name: G0 No handwashing facility
G1 Jerrycan or other closed container
G1 Portable basin or other open container
G1 Other temporary handwashing facility
G3 Piped water tap with basin
G3 Market handwashing station with adequate water storage
G3 Other permanent handwashing station

questions.question: Hands-free operation of institutional handwashing facility

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: mechanism to collect water or trigger water flow 
Hands-free operation: the handwashing station is operated by tap, or other hands-free mechanism that minimises contact with the water collection device and the water container

options.name: "G0 Hands enter the water container (during collection and use) "
G1 Water collected by hand (using ladle, cup, other)
G3 Closed water storage container with tap
G3 Piped water tap
G3 Other hands-free operation

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: facility to collect washing water, and facility to drain and dispose of the washing water
Collection of washing water: container to collect dirty washing water (for example, a basin or other container)
Drainage and disposal of washing water: drainage pipe or other facility to direct the washing water to an appropriate disposal point (for example, a soakpit or drain)

options.name: "G0 No collection or disposal of washing water "
G1 Collection of washing water without drainage or disposal
G3 Safe collection and disposal of washing water
